artworks.title: Three Graces of Cova d'Or (Woman's Face)

artists.name: Salvador Dalí
artists.blurb: Salvador Dalí was a leading proponent of [Surrealism](/gene/surrealism), the 20-century avant-garde movement that sought to release the creative potential of the unconscious through strange, dream-like imagery. “[Surrealism](/gene/surrealism) is destructive, but it destroys only what it considers to be shackles limiting our vision,” he said. Dalí is specially credited with the innovation of “paranoia-criticism,” a philosophy of art making he defined as “irrational understanding based on the interpretive-critical association of delirious phenomena.” In addition to meticulously painting fantastic compositions, such as _The Accommodations of Desire_ (1929) and the [melting clocks](/collection/salvador-dali-melting-clocks) in his famed _The Persistence of Memory_ (1931), Dalí was a prolific writer and early filmmaker, and cultivated an eccentric public persona with his flamboyant mustache, pet ocelot, and outlandish behavior and quips. “Each morning when I awake, I experience again a supreme pleasure,” he once said. “That of being Salvador Dalí.”

artists.name: Joan Miró
artists.bio: Spanish, 1893-1983, Barcelona, Spain, based in Paris and Catalonia, Spain
artists.blurb: Joan Miró rejected the constraints of traditional painting, creating works “conceived with fire in the soul but executed with clinical coolness,” as he once said. Widely considered one of the leading [Surrealists](/gene/surrealism), though never officially part of the group, Miró pioneered a wandering linear style of [Automatism](/gene/automatism)—a method of “random” drawing that attempted to express the inner workings of the human psyche. Miró used color and form in a symbolic rather than literal manner, his intricate compositions combining abstract elements with recurring motifs like birds, eyes, and the moon. “I try to apply colors like words that shape poems, like notes that shape music,” he said. While he prized artistic freedom, Miró revered art history, basing a series of works on the Dutch [Baroque](/gene/baroque) interiors of Hendrick Sorgh and Jan Steen. In turn, Miró has inspired many artists—significantly [Arshile Gorky](/artist/arshile-gorky), whose bold linear abstractions proved a foundational influence on [Abstract Expressionism](/gene/abstract-expressionism).

artists.name: Shepard Fairey
artists.bio: American, born 1970, Charleston, SC, United States, based in Los Angeles, CA, United States
artists.blurb: Expanding on the legacies of artists such as [Keith Haring](/artist/keith-haring) and [Andy Warhol](/artist/andy-warhol), Shepard Fairey’s practice disrupts the distinction between fine and commercial art. A major artist of the [street art](/gene/street-art) movement, Fairey rose to prominence in the early 1990s through the dispersion of posters, stickers, and murals, related to his [Obey Giant](/collection/shepard-fairey-andre-the-giant) campaign, which yielded an international cultural phenomenon. Fairey’s iconic poster of [President Barack Obama](/collection/shepard-fairey-barack-obama) was adopted as the official emblem associated with the presidential campaign and encapsulates a number of recurring concerns in the artist’s work, including propaganda, portraiture, and [political power](/collection/shepard-fairey-political-portraits).
